column4: hey there, i'm trying to get the wireless working on my samsung n130 netbook. I have it working but it sometimes times out, and sometimes it takes ages to resolve domains. It takes next to no time to access local IPs
google bind9 cache config
will do
I'm not sure what to do with this? What are you suggesting I do?
i am suggesting dns caching with bind9. It will cache websites that you commonly use in a dns cache.
do you have a love for firefox or are you willing to switch to chromium?
is there no way to actually fix the problem I'm having with the wireless? (ethernet is perfect)
I use chromium already ;)

then DNS caching is your best bet. If you visit google.com alot, then it keeps the ip address to google.com in the cache and doesn't reconnect to the dns server every request, just every time the cache link expires.
i guess you're right
for whatever reason, Ubuntu's networking mechanism seems to be incompetent in terms of its dns caching capibilities
I've been trying to get past this annoying limitation for the past 2.5 hours, you have given me a silver lining of sorts :P
aah - this is a netbook :S
then in edit connections, select wireless -> your wireless access point -> edit -> IPv4 Settings, set method to automatic dhcp addresses only, and set the dns servers to "8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4"
result! I actually tried that with opendns instead of google's dns. For some annoying reason it works now!
